components.text: Students may actually feel a little drained, physically or emotionally worn down during a placement, some students may find working full time exhausting. Especially, those students who need extra time to study because they have a Specific Learning Difficulty, or those students who work and have caring responsibilities.
The work place is challenging and it is the students’ responsibility to ensure they are adequately prepared. However, some students may approach staff if they have challenging times.

This section will highlight some key tips for supporting students on placement. Placements are an unusual learning environment for students, and staff could provide reassurance and support to students who are struggling.

At this point, the ball is the student’s court. The University has prepared the students and hopefully most of them will have successful placements. Though it’s the students’ responsibility to learn and demonstrate the skills and competencies they have learned on placement, it is the duty of education providers to ensure students are treated fairly and that the education we provide is inclusive.
Inclusion is a process that helps overcome barriers limiting the presence, participation and achievement of learners.
components.author: UNESCO

components.text: Equity is about ensuring that there is a concern with fairness, such that the education of all learners is seen as having equal importance.
components.author: UNESCO

components.title: A guide for ensuring inclusion and equity in education

components.text: Inclusive Education practices are steadily becoming mainstream, since the Equality Act was introduced in 2010. However, implementing some inclusive practices may be challenging. Some placement providers may not know how to make learning inclusive, University staff can provide guidance and training. Staff at the University can liaise with the placement providers to build capacity and raise awareness, providing guidance and support to enable educators and mentors support students.
The following two documents refer to supporting students with Asperger's Syndrome, however the advice given applies for students with other disabilities as well.

links.text: Advice for lecturers supporting students with Asperger's Syndrome ( MMU)

components.text: Staff can access training to support their understanding of the various policies and processes that affect students with disabilities on placement.

Organisation Development regularly has short training programmes (2- 4 hours) which focus on support for students with disabilities. For example, Supporting disabled learners – Autism awareness – 2 Hour training or Supporting disabled learners – Introduction to supporting students who are blind or have a visual impairment – 2 Hour training.
The Academic Development team can also provide bespoke training on any particular topic.

Staff can access the Disability Team if they need support engaging with a student. The disabilities team can support staff by offering advice, tips and skills to address challenges students with disabilities may have.
If you have any questions contact the team.

The section highlighted issues around supporting students on placement, particularly how staff can enable educators and mentors provide inclusive education and how staff can access support from the disability team.
